answers.text: a self-ascending elevator with its own propulsion

qas.question: What settings are climbing elevators used in?

answers.text: an observation tower in Glasgow, Scotland

qas.question: How is the propulsion powered in a climbing elevator?

answers.text: by an electric or a combustion engine

context: A climbing elevator is <a0_0>a self-ascending elevator with its own propulsion<a0_0/>. The propulsion can be done <a3_0>by an electric or a combustion engine<a3_0/>. Climbing elevators are used in <a1_0>guyed masts or towers<a1_0/>, in order to make easy access to parts of these constructions, such as flight safety lamps for maintenance. An example would be the Moonlight towers in Austin, Texas, where the elevator holds only one person and equipment for maintenance. The Glasgow Tower — <a2_0>an observation tower in Glasgow, Scotland<a2_0/> — also makes use of two climbing elevators.
